articles.headline: Pakistan and Afghan Taliban Close Ranks
articles.snippet: Mullah Muhammad Omar, the Afghan Taliban leader, persuaded the Pakistani Taliban to focus their efforts on the fight in Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: Mullah Muhammad Omar, the Afghan Taliban leader, persuaded the Pakistani Taliban to focus their efforts on the fight in Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  After agreeing to bury their differences and unite forces, Taliban leaders based in Pakistan have closed ranks with their Afghan comrades to ready a new offensive in Afghanistan as the United States prepares to send 17,000 more troops there this year.

articles.headline: Clash of Subways and Car Culture in Chinese Cities
articles.snippet: Auto sales are jumping while immense subway systems are being built for commuters in China’s metropolises.
articles.abstract: Auto sales are jumping while immense subway systems are being built for commuters in China’s metropolises.
articles.lead_paragraph: GUANGZHOU, China  Chan Shao Zhang is in the race of his life.

articles.headline: Rising Fear of a Future Oil Shock
articles.snippet: Reductions in investments and low oil prices could curb future supplies, leaving the world to face a new energy shock when the economy picks up, according to a study.
articles.abstract: Reductions in investments and low oil prices could curb future supplies, leaving the world to face a new energy shock when the economy picks up, according to a study.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sharp reductions in investments and low oil prices could curb future supplies by almost eight million barrels a day within the next five years, according to a study scheduled for release Friday, the latest warning that the world could face a new energy shock when the economy picks up.

articles.headline: Aided by Safety Nets, Europe Resists Stimulus Push
articles.snippet: Europe says its safety nets automatically provide the spending that the United States Congress has to legislate.
articles.abstract: Europe says its safety nets automatically provide the spending that the United States Congress has to legislate.
articles.lead_paragraph: VIENENBURG, Germany  Last month Frank Koppe gathered together all 50 of his employees at Koppe-Apparatebau for coffee, cake and the kind of bad news that has lately become all too familiar. He told them the small company’s business, designing and manufacturing custom equipment for industrial plants, had been sliced nearly in half.

articles.headline: A Downturn Wraps a City in Hesitance
articles.snippet: In cities like Portland, Ore., there is a crisis of economic expectations, as the creditworthy choose not to invest.
articles.abstract: In cities like Portland, Ore., there is a crisis of economic expectations, as the creditworthy choose not to invest.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore.  Over the last four decades, Powell’s Books has swelled into the largest bookstore in North America  a capacious monument to reading that occupies a full square block of this often-drizzly city. But this year, growth has given way to anxiety.

articles.headline: Inquiry Asks Why A.I.G. Paid Banks
articles.snippet: Lawmakers and the New York attorney general began inquiries into how tens of billions of taxpayer dollars moved from A.I.G. to several dozen big banks.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers and the New York attorney general began inquiries into how tens of billions of taxpayer dollars moved from A.I.G. to several dozen big banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Members of Congress and the New York State attorney general demanded detailed information Thursday on how tens of billions of taxpayer dollars flowed through the American International Group during its crisis last fall and ended up in the coffers of several dozen big banks, shielding them from losses.

articles.headline: When Stars Twitter, a Ghost May Be Lurking
articles.snippet: A need for constant updates has created a cottage industry that fans may not be aware of: Twitter ghostwriters.
articles.abstract: A need for constant updates has created a cottage industry that fans may not be aware of: Twitter ghostwriters.
articles.lead_paragraph: The rapper 50 Cent is among the legion of stars who have recently embraced Twitter to reach fans who crave near-continuous access to their lives and thoughts. On March 1, he shared this insight with the more than 200,000 people who follow him: “My ambition leads me through a tunnel that never ends.”

articles.headline: Stock Options Are Adjusted After Many Share Prices Fall
articles.snippet: In an effort to retain workers, executives at dozens of public companies have taken steps to lower the prices that their employees would have to pay to convert options into stock.
articles.abstract: In an effort to retain workers, executives at dozens of public companies have taken steps to lower the prices that their employees would have to pay to convert options into stock.
articles.lead_paragraph: Employee pay is often tied to a company’s fortune  until things turn sour.
